linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 1 provides the results of performed studies for determination of natural fracturing at the fields of this region. It is worth noting that the same reservoir C1t-D3fm (T-Fm) was selected for the comparison of results in equal conditions.

The dipole full-waveform logging and electrical microscanner studies were performed in three wells 4, 215 (dipole full-waveform logging) and 113 (electrical microscanner). Fracturing intervals were identified on the basis of research results. Figures 2–3 below show the results of these studies.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Graphical presentation of the dipole full-waveform logging data on the basis of the assessment of fracturing and stress condition of rocks as per the data of dipole probes in the interval of 2625.0 – 2710.0 m (C1t+C1t-D3fm) in Well 4

formatted-caption.caption-text: Graphical presentation of the dipole full-waveform logging data on the basis of the assessment of fracturing and stress condition of rocks as per the data of dipole probes in the interval of 2625.0 – 2710.0 m (C1t+C1t-D3fm) in Well 4

linkTarget.anchoringText: The dipole full-waveform logging and electrical microscanner studies were performed in three wells 4, 215 (dipole full-waveform logging) and 113 (electrical microscanner). Fracturing intervals were identified on the basis of research results. Figures 2–3 below show the results of these studies.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Graphical presentation of the dipole full-waveform logging data on the basis of the assessment of fracturing and stress condition of rocks as per the data of dipole probes in the interval of 2084.6 – 2140.0 m (C1t+C1t-D3fm) in Well 215

formatted-caption.caption-text: Graphical presentation of the dipole full-waveform logging data on the basis of the assessment of fracturing and stress condition of rocks as per the data of dipole probes in the interval of 2084.6 – 2140.0 m (C1t+C1t-D3fm) in Well 215

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to the results of indicator studies (Figure 4) the closure of fractures in the set range of depressions (up to saturation pressure) is not observed, which testifies to a high energy potential of the deposit.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Studies with the indicator diagram building method in wells 4, 3, 2 (left to right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Studies with the indicator diagram building method in wells 4, 3, 2 (left to right)

linkTarget.anchoringText: At the initial stage of updating of the geological and hydrodynamic model with account of the analysis of the whole performed surveys range, the type of the conceptual model was selected, describing the chosen research target most completely. The classification of R. Nelson [2] was used for that, according to which four types of reservoirs are identified depending on the ratio of matrix and fracture properties (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Types of fractured reservoirs as per the classification of Ronald Nelson

formatted-caption.caption-text: Types of fractured reservoirs as per the classification of Ronald Nelson

linkTarget.anchoringText: Since the genesis of fracture formation is preconditioned not by tectonic processes (voids are complicated by vugs), the fracturing parameters depend on sedimentation indicators of carbonate rocks and are similar in the same facies. Therefore, in the process of geological simulation a map of facies distribution prepared on the basis of the seismofacial analysis (Figure 6) was used as a trend for fracturing distribution in the reservoir volume.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Combined map of seismofacial analysis and core studies and well logging data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Combined map of seismofacial analysis and core studies and well logging data

linkTarget.anchoringText: Simplification of the effective fracture system till several equivalent parameters is the result of geological simulation of the double environment. I.e. two 3D cubes with porosity parameters for the porous and fracture type of the reservoir and permeability cubes for axes X and Y were received as the result (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Map of distribution of permeability with account of fractures (along X and Y)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of distribution of permeability with account of fractures (along X and Y)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Therefore, the geological and hydrodynamic model was updated on the basis of completed comprehensive analysis of all information. The mathematic model of double porosity received allowed for further hydrodynamic calculations taking into account the factors determining the real pattern of liquid filtration through the fractured reservoir, which in turn led to improvement of adaptation of the calculated reservoir pressure dynamics in wells (Figure 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Diagram of comparison of calculated and actual reservoir and bottomhole pressure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diagram of comparison of calculated and actual reservoir and bottomhole pressure

linkTarget.anchoringText: Therefore, the series of multivariant calculations was formed, within the frames of which different HWB drilling directions were considered (Figure 9). These variants, in addition to the existing wells (7 producing wells), provide for drilling of 2 designed producing wells with horizontal layout (Nos. 116, 323) with multi-stage hydraulic fracturing and 1 injection well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Map of density of mobile oil reserves with account of multivariant calculations of HWB directions by wells 116, 323

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of density of mobile oil reserves with account of multivariant calculations of HWB directions by wells 116, 323
